ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I thought this course was instrumental in teaching me the next steps that I should take post college to further my artistic career.
How to create a professional portfolio, how to describe artistic work in concise and compelling ways, how to approach artistic work through an academic lens

This course was very helpful in organizing my thinking for my THST senior project. I also learned practical skills, like how to give a design presentation, how to discuss my work at various stages of progress, how to create an artistic portfolio, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think one of the strengths of the course is that it has some of the best minds in Theatre Studies to help solve production problems etc. I think one of the weakness are that the days we have critiques need to be more structured so that executive producers receive more constructive feedback about the production itself rather than the research and theory involved.

There are a number of weaknesses in the course that students have pointed out over several years. In my view, the main one is the fact that, while its main purpose is to supply the academic research and serve as a "brain trust", it sometimes becomes an obstacle from achieving that very goal. It detracts from the time seniors could spend (the way the playwrights spend it) on developing the work and putting the research together. The class really doesn't need to be that long, especially during the non-critique sessions. The main strength of the class are the students -- hearing about their experience making the work and reflecting on it is its most valuable asset.

Strengths: Creating a space where seniors can solicit feedback/thoughts about their senior projects. Weaknesses: I think one of the difficult things about this course is the balance between having it be about the senior projects and having it be about the "portfolio" and other things meant to prepare seniors for working in theater beyond Yale. At times, it felt frustrating to have to be focusing so much time and energy on the "theater beyond Yale" elements of the course, when our senior projects require most of our attention for the semester. I also wonder how effective it is for seniors to write their paper at the same time that they are carrying out their senior project. It seems like the intellectual inquiry should happen prior to the project's execution, but the current schedule makes the paper (and supposed intellectual inquiry contained within) feel like an afterthought. What if the senior paper had to be completed in the spring of junior year as a precursor to the project? Or in the summer before senior year? Or what if there were 2 stages of the paper - one prior to the project's execution and a shorter one after to discuss the effectiveness of the project in carrying out the research goals, etc.? In any case, I think some thinking could go into how to more effectively integrate the paper and the project (without taking much-needed time and energy away from the execution of the project).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this class to students doing senior thesis production, even if you are just writing a play. The course really is good for creating those first portfolios that you will eventually have to send to grad schools.
This seminar is actually very valuable for senior THST majors carrying out senior production projects. It's nice to have a group of people to talk to/commiserate with throughout the process.
